SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: How does paragraph 9 contribute to the development of a theme in the story?

A.Choice: by suggesting that Aven often observes herself

B.Choice: by describing the care Aven puts into her appearance

C.Choice: by showing Aven is worried about what people think

D.Choice: by illustrating how Aven prepares herself for a performance

SubTopics: Analyze how a particular sentence, chapter, scene, or stanza fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the theme, setting, or plot.
Content: How does paragraph 13 mainly develop the character of the narrator?

A.Choice: by informing the reader that the guitar belonged to the narrator's mother

B.Choice: by telling the reader that the narrator found the guitar in a storage closet

C.Choice: by informing the reader that the narrator's parents were watching her

D.Choice: by telling the reader about the type of shoes the narrator wears while performing

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: What is the effect of the narrator's repetition of the word “me” in paragraph 14?

A.Choice: She thinks the audience is impressed with her ability to play the guitar.

B.Choice: She hopes people will notice the objects which belong to her mother.

C.Choice: She thinks it is remarkable that she is performing in front of an audience.

D.Choice: She hopes that people appreciate how much she practiced during the week.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 6 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: What does the word “insignificant” mean as it is used in paragraph 15?

A.Choice: talentless

B.Choice: brave

C.Choice: unimportant

D.Choice: accepted

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: Which phrase from paragraph 15 best conveys a theme of the story?

A.Choice: “the fireworks exploded”

B.Choice: “the lights of the city”

C.Choice: “millions of people”

D.Choice: “the light was in me”

SubTopics: Describe how a particular story's or drama's plot unfolds in a series of episodes as well as how the characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution.
Content: Which detail best represents how Aven changes at the end of the story?

A.Choice: “... plucked at a string with one not quite steady toe.” (paragraph 13)

B.Choice: “... I saw that all their eyes were on me ...” (paragraph 14)

C.Choice: “... arms around each other, swaying to the music.” (paragraph 14)

D.Choice: “I felt as big as the giant saguaro ...” (paragraph 15)

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: Read this phrase from paragraph 15.
:box:I felt like I was shining ...
Which sentence best represents the meaning of this phrase?

A.Choice: Aven feels proud of who she is.

B.Choice: Aven is looking forward to more performances.

C.Choice: Aven understands she is more important than others.

D.Choice: Aven is relieved the audience enjoyed her performance.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: Which statement represents a central claim of the article?

A.Choice: Environments often influence career choices.

B.Choice: Bats are misunderstood creatures who need protecting.

C.Choice: Photographs can help people overcome their fears of the unknown.

D.Choice: Bats often travel a great distance when they migrate.

SubTopics: Analyze in detail how a key individual, event, or idea is introduced, illustrated, and elaborated in a text (e.g., through examples or anecdotes).
Content: What does the information presented in the last two lines of paragraph 3 illustrate?

A.Choice: People forced the bats to leave the cave.

B.Choice: Bats had already migrated to another place.

C.Choice: People enjoyed using the cave for activities.

D.Choice: Bats left the cave because of the amount of garbage.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings.
Content: Why does the author use words like “Misguided” (paragraph 3) and “misunderstand” (paragraph 4) in the article?

A.Choice: to suggest that bats have been the victims of myths

B.Choice: to emphasize why a solution to bat removal is needed

C.Choice: to explain why many bats travel great distances every year

D.Choice: to indicate that books do not always give accurate information about bats

SubTopics: Analyze in detail how a key individual, event, or idea is introduced, illustrated, and elaborated in a text (e.g., through examples or anecdotes).
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 3.
:box:“Everywhere I went, people were killing bats in large numbers just out of ignorance,” says Merlin.
Which quotation from the article best explains the cause of the “ignorance” described by Merlin?

A.Choice: “... Merlin figured out that the books were wrong.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “Many people are afraid of bats.” (paragraph 3)

C.Choice: “What he found shocked him.” (paragraph 3)

D.Choice: “Bats fly at night and spend the day in dark places.” (paragraph 5)

SubTopics: Analyze how a particular sentence, paragraph, chapter, or section fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the ideas.
Content: What is the main way paragraph 5 helps develop ideas in the article?

A.Choice: by explaining the habits of bats during daytime hours

B.Choice: by describing the stress bats often experience

C.Choice: by explaining why Merlin is interested in bat photographs

D.Choice: by describing how Merlin helps people better understand bats

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: Which detail would be most important to include in a summary of the article?

A.Choice: Merlin Tuttle studied bats and helped educate the public about their importance.

B.Choice: Farmers told Merlin Tuttle that bats were bad for their fruit trees and crops.

C.Choice: Merlin Tuttle earned a degree in advanced mammalogy when he was in college.

D.Choice: People told Merlin Tuttle they were afraid of bats when he talked to them.

SubTopics: Analyze in detail how a key individual, event, or idea is introduced, illustrated, and elaborated in a text (e.g., through examples or anecdotes).
Content: How does the author develop an important idea in the article?

A.Choice: by describing Merlin's discovery of gray bat migration, which shows how ideas can change

B.Choice: by referring to traditional photographs of bats, which make bats appear to be threatening

C.Choice: by describing Merlin's effort to inform people about bats, which shows the importance of education

D.Choice: by referring to caves where bats live, which indicates that ideas may sometimes be based on fear

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 6 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: What does the word “brittle” mean as it is used in paragraph 3?

A.Choice: very valuable

B.Choice: cold to the touch

C.Choice: easily broken

D.Choice: hard to read

SubTopics: Describe how a particular story's or drama's plot unfolds in a series of episodes as well as how the characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution.
Content: How does Milo respond to the discovery of the map?

A.Choice: with slight nervousness

B.Choice: with intense curiosity

C.Choice: with extreme astonishment

D.Choice: with mild amusement

SubTopics: Describe how a particular story's or drama's plot unfolds in a series of episodes as well as how the characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution.
Content: How does the plot change in paragraphs 8 through 10?

A.Choice: Someone arrives in search of Milo.

B.Choice: Milo hides the wallet in the shed.

C.Choice: Someone arrives in search of the wallet.

D.Choice: A guest departs because of the snow.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: Read this quotation from paragraph 10.
:box:Still, when the dark shadow swung itself back up off the tracks, something made Milo edge deeper into the shed and tuck himself as far behind the winch as he could.
What effect does this quotation have on the tone of the story?

A.Choice: It adds to the mysterious tone.

B.Choice: It introduces a judging tone.

C.Choice: It creates a discouraged tone.

D.Choice: It establishes a concerned tone.

SubTopics: Describe how a particular story's or drama's plot unfolds in a series of episodes as well as how the characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution.
Content: How do Milo's actions in paragraphs 9 through 11 contribute to the development of the plot?

A.Choice: by revealing his intention to keep the wallet

B.Choice: by showing that he fears the guest in the pavilion

C.Choice: by suggesting that he knows there are more maps

D.Choice: by emphasizing his preference for being alone

SubTopics: Explain how an author develops the point of view of the narrator or speaker in a text.
Content: The author mainly develops Milo's point of view by

A.Choice: expressing Milo's opinion about where the map leads

B.Choice: revealing Milo's thoughts about his discovery and the guest

C.Choice: commenting on Milo's decision to keep the wallet

D.Choice: explaining Milo's unwillingness to communicate with the guest

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: Which detail would be most important to include in a summary of the story?

A.Choice: Milo notices that the paper has a watermark.

B.Choice: Milo turns the map so that the compass rose points north.

C.Choice: Milo sees that the guest is wearing a heavy coat.

D.Choice: Milo hides in the shed until the person outside leaves.

SubTopics: Analyze how a particular sentence, chapter, scene, or stanza fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the theme, setting, or plot.
Content: How does paragraph 3 fit into the structure of “[Excerpt from] A Legend of the Wooden Shoes”? Use two details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: In paragraph 8, how does the power of the old oak tree support a theme of the story? Use two details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: Explain how an author develops the point of view of the narrator or speaker in a text.
Content: In “[Excerpt from] A Legend of the Wooden Shoes,” how does the carpenter's point of view change throughout the story? Use two details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and explain how it is conveyed in the text.
Content: Based on paragraphs 6 and 13, what is the author's purpose for writing the article? Use two details from the article to support your response.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: What is the central message of the article “[Excerpt from] In Omaha, A Library With No Books Brings Technology to All ”? Use two details from the article to support your response.

SubTopics: Analyze how a particular sentence, paragraph, chapter, or section fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the ideas.
Content: In the article “[Excerpt from] In Omaha, A Library With No Books Brings Technology to All,” how do paragraphs 10 and 15 support the author's central idea? Use two details from the article to support your response.

Topics: Informational Text - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Compare and contrast one author's presentation of events with that of another (e.g., a memoir written by and a biography on the same person).
Content: The authors of the articles “[Excerpt from] Thomas Jefferson Builds a Library ” and “[Excerpt from] In Omaha, A Library With No Books Brings Technology to All ” present information about two important libraries. How were these libraries established? How are these libraries similar and different? Use evidence from both articles to support your response.

:box:In your response, be sure to describe how the libraries were established

• explain how these libraries are similar
• explain how these libraries are different
• use details from both articles to support your response
